bibl.title: Letter from Marshall L. Price to Howard A. Kelly, October 19, 1907

div1.p: Price writes about Carroll's experience in the military, particularly under the command of his father. He corrects misconceptions regarding his father's role in Carroll's career.

div1.head: Letter from Marshall L. Price to Howard A. Kelly, October 19, 1907
div1.opener:
V
FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
State Board of Health
OF MARYLAND
8 AND 10 SOUTH STREET
BALTIMORE, October 19th.1907
WM. H. WELCH, M. D., PRESIDENT
DR. EUGENE JONES
DR. LOUIS A. GRIFFITH
DR. JAMES BOSLEY
MR. DOUGLAS H. THOMAS, JR.
HON. WM. S. BRYAN, JR.
John H. FULTON, M.D., SECRETARY
MARSHALL LANGTON PRICE M.D. Secretary.
Dear Doctor Kelly;-
div1.p:
I have taken advantage of your note of October 15th.
which I found awaiting me on my return from Cambridge to make you a
rather voluminous reply. I had personally no share in Carroll's early
work though I have aided in every way which I could in the work of
his professional and other friends to secure recognition of his ser-
vices,-as much through a sense of justice as on account of my person-
al friendship for him.

My only reason for referring to the statements of Dr. Jas. Pilcher was
to give you my reasons for believing them in the main untrue, though I may
have attached undue importance to them at the time. I believe that
Carroll referred to Pilchers remarks at the time they were made but
neither of us thaen attached any importance to them. I feel however
that Carroll's death has placed them in a new aspect, first because I
belive that Carroll will occupy a high place in future medical history
and second I have a strong objection to what appears to me to be an
attempt to exploit a dead man for personal advancement.

My own acquaintance with Carroll began at Fort Custer Montana in about
1884 or 1885. At that time my father Curtis E. Price was surgeon of the
Post and Drs. Pilcher and Beach were his assistants. I saw Carroll
in the Laboratory of Dr. LaGarde of the Army again in 1893 at the Col-
umbian Exposition at Chicago but did not recognize him. The first
time I renewed my acquaintance with him from the time he left Ft.
Custer was at the New Orleans meeting of the AM.M.A. where he and I
read papers the same day, this was in 1903. Dr. Pilcher did not meet
FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY.
2.
him or avery see him again as far as I know subsequent to 1884.
Dr. Carroll at that time was my father's Hospital Steward. I believe
that it was while stationed at Ft. Custer that Carroll decided to study
medecine though while I remember Carroll well I of course had no re-
collection of this plan then and did not have until Carroll told me
in recent years. According to what Carroll told me he stated his de-
sire to my father and requested a detail at St. Paul Minn. so that he
could attend the medical lectures there. His application was approv-
ed and forewarded in accordance with the military regulations to Col.
N.A.M. Dudley, Bvt. Brig. Gen. Commanding Officer of the Post who dis-
proved it and returned the papers to the Post Surgeon, with an endorse-
ment reading about as follows,-“this man desires to educate himself
with the object of leaving the service, his application is disapproved”.

The reason for Gen. Dudley's unfavorable endorsement was one of the
petty affairs which persons not born in the Army would hardly apprec-
iate and which those of us not acquainted with Army tradition and feeling
are apt to condemn too severely. My recollection is that my father
secured the detail over the head of the Commanding Officer, not as I
believe through any special recognition of Carroll's ability and char-
acter but because he would have made the same fight with pleasure and
enthusiasm for any of the men of ability, ambition and good character
of his command. Doubtless he also was in part determined to press the
matter through resentment of what he must have considered an unwarrented
interference with the affairs of his department. In the matter of
Carroll's departure from Ft. Custer Mont. to Ft. Snelling Minn., Dr. Pilcher
did not have and could not have any part, as he remained my father's asst-
istant at the Post until he was ordered away, and Carroll left imediately
upon receipt of his orders to go to Fort Snelling at St. Paul where he
began his medical education which was to continue with many interrupt-
ions for about ten years of life in the ranks of the Army, at Omaha,
FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
3.
at New York, and at Baltimore. I fail to see how Dr. Pilcher could if
he would, have been of any material assistance to Carroll during this
time and my knowledge of Pilcher (all hearsay, and dating twenty years
back) does not incline me to put great faith in his absolute veracity.

If you consider this an important part of Carroll's rise the facts
could no doubt be ascertained at first hand from the Army records and the
surviving officers of the 1st. and 2nd. Cavalry and 17th., 3rd. and 5th.
Infantry stationed at Ft? Custer in the early eighties. I believe
moreover from the few words Carroll and myself exchanged on the subject
of Dr. Pilcher indifference if not dislike was the only feeling existing
between them.

You are at liberty to make use of this letter in any way you think proper
but I would prefer that my father's name would not appear in the light
of a benefactor to Carroll. I am as unwilling as he would be to have
him credited with results for which he was in no way responsible, and
I am sure that if he were living and were credited with the “discovery”
of Carroll he would be both surprised and amused. I feel strongly
that one man was responsible for Carroll's rise and that was James
Carroll, and that his rise after a life of fifty years of not alone ob-
scurity, but submersion shows the remarkable material of which the man
was made whom I shall always be glad to count as a friend.
